name: title
text: Watch what happens when you refactor code that's tested with mocks.

name: show_service
text: Here's a typical email service. It imports smtplib directly and sends messages through SMTP.

name: show_mock_test
text: The test uses at-patch to mock smtplib, asserting on starttls, login, and send message. Everything passes.

name: explain_refactor
text: Now the business says switch from SMTP to a REST API. Same behavior, different transport. We refactor the service to use an HTTP endpoint instead.

name: mock_breaks
text: We run the same mock test and it explodes. The mock was patching app dot smtplib, which no longer exists. The test was coupled to the implementation, not the behavior.

name: show_dioxide
text: Now here's the dioxide way. The service depends on an email port protocol. It doesn't know or care whether emails go through SMTP, an API, or a carrier pigeon.

name: show_fake_test
text: The test uses a simple fake. Seven lines of code. It records what was sent and lets us assert on the result.

name: fake_survives
text: Same refactoring. Same test. It passes. Because the fake implements the port, not the implementation.

name: closing
text: Mocks couple to how. Fakes couple to what. That's why fakes survive refactoring.
